facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 37 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 37 of 1965.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1964 and Death Reference No. 9 of 1964.

facts.text: Patna High Court judgment in Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1964 and Death Reference No. 9 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 9, 1964 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 200 of 1964 and Death Reference No. 9 of 1964.

facts.text: Appellant charged under section 302 IPC for murdering aunt Ratni, daughter Chamin, son-in-law Somra, and Dilu son of Somra.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code for murdering his aunt, Ratni, her daugh- ter. Chamin, her son-in-law, Somra and Dilu, son of somra.

facts.text: Appellant convicted and sentenced to death by Judicial Commissioner of Chotanagpur.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyvicted and sentenced to death by the Judicial Commis- sioner of Chotanagpur.

facts.text: Patna High Court accepted death reference, confirmed conviction and sentence, dismissed appellant's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna accepted the death reference, companyfirmed the companyviction and sentence and dismissed the appeal preferred by the appellant.

facts.text: On August 11, 1963 between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m., appellant murdered Somra in Dungijharan Hills forest.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that on August 11, 1963 between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. the appellant murdered Somra in a forest known as Dungijharan Hills

facts.text: Appellant murdered Chamin in Kesari Garha field on August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and later Chamin in Kesari Garha field and then Ratni and Dilu in the house of Ratni at village Jamtoli.

facts.text: Appellant murdered Ratni and Dilu in Ratni's house at village Jamtoli on August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and later Chamin in Kesari Garha field and then Ratni and Dilu in the house of Ratni at village Jamtoli.

facts.text: First information lodged by appellant at Palkot police station on August 11, 1963 at 3:15 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The first information of the offences was lodged by the appellant himself at police station Palkot on August 11, 1963 at 3-15 p.m.

facts.text: FIR reduced to writing by Sub-Inspector H.P. Choudhury, appellant affixed left thumb impression.

anchor.surface_text: The information was reduced to writing by the officerin-charge, Sub-Inspector H. P. Choudhury, and the appellant affixed his left thumb-impression on the report.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector took cognizance of offence and arrested appellant immediately after FIR.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub Inspector immediately took companynizance of the offence, and arrested the appellant.

facts.text: On August 12, 1963, Sub-Inspector with appellant went to Ratni's house; appellant pointed out dead bodies of Ratni and Dilu and place where tangi concealed.

anchor.surface_text: The next day, the Sub Inspector in the companypany of the appellant went to the house of Ratni, where the appellant pointed out the dead bodies of Ratni and Dilu and also a place in the orchard of Ratni companyered with bushes and grass, where he had companycealed a tangi.

facts.text: Appellant pointed out dead body of Chamin in ditch covered with Ghanghu in Kasiari garha khet.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took the Sub Inspector and witnesses to Kasiari garha khet and pointed out the dead body of Chamin lying in a ditch companyered with Ghanghu.

facts.text: Appellant pointed out dead body of Somra on slope of hills to the north in Dungijharan Hills.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then took the Sub Inspector and the witnesses to Dungijharan Hills, where he pointed out the dead body of Somra lying in the slope of the hills to the numberth.

facts.text: Blood-stained chadar recovered from appellant's house.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub Inspector also recovered from the appellants house a chadar stained with human blood.

facts.text: P.W. 6 evidence shows appellant went to forest on morning of August 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of P.W. 6 shows that the appellant had gone to the forest on the morning of August 11, 1963.

facts.text: Medical evidence: incised wounds on all dead bodies caused by sharp-cutting weapon such as tangi.

anchor.surface_text: The medical evidence discloses incised wounds on all the dead bodies. The injuries were caused by a sharp-cutting weapon such as a tangi.

facts.text: All four persons brutally murdered; no eyewitness to murders.

anchor.surface_text: All the four persons were brutally murdered. There is numbereye-witness to the murders.

facts.text: Appellant is Aghnu Nagesia, son of Lodhi Nagesia, resident of Lotwa, Tola Jamtoli, thana Palkot, district Ranchi.

anchor.surface_text: My name is Aghnu Nagesia.  1  My fathers name is Lodhi Nagesia. I am a resident of Lotwa, Tola Jamtoli, thana Palkot, district Ranchi.

facts.text: Motive: Quarrels due to aunt giving property to daughter and son-in-law; appellant expected to inherit as aunt had son and was widow.

anchor.surface_text: that on account of my Barima  aunt  Mussammat having given away her property to her daughter and son-in-law quarrels and troubles have been occurring among us. My Barima has numberson and she is a widow.

facts.text: Appellant went with tangi to Duni Jharan Pahar at 7-8 a.m. on August 11, 1963 to cut shrubs.

anchor.surface_text: Today in the morning at about 7-8 a.m. I had -one with a tangi to Duni Jharan Pahar to cut shrubs for fencing.

facts.text: Appellant narrated occurrence to chacha Lerha that he killed the four persons.

anchor.surface_text: Later on I narrated the occurrence to my chacha  fathers brother  Lerha that I killed the aforesaid four persons with tangi.

concepts.interpretation: No confession made to a police officer shall be proved as against a person accused of an offence. Absolute ban on confessions to police officers under any circumstances, extending to the entire confessional statement including all incriminating facts.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: erson accused of an offence. The terms of s. 25 are imperative. A companyfession made to a police officer under any circumstances is number admissible

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 25 of the Indian Evidence Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits proof of confessions made to a police officer.

anchor.surface_text: Section 27 is in the form of a proviso, and partially lifts the ban imposed by ss. 24, 25 and 26. It provides that when any fact is deposed to as discovered in companysequence of information received from a person accused of any offence, in the custody of a police officer, so much of such information, whether it amounts to a companyfession or number, as relates distinctly to the fact thereby discovered, may be proved.

concepts.interpretation: Partially lifts the ban of ss.24-26 for information leading to discovery of facts, applied to appellant's information leading to discovery of dead bodies and tangi.

concepts.interpretation: Excludes confessions caused by inducement, threat or promise; taint affects entire statement.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 24 of the Indian Evidence Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Excludes confessions by inducement, threat or promise.

anchor.surface_text: Section 26 prohibits proof against any person of a companyfession made by him in the custody of a police officer, unless it is made in the immediate presence of a Magistrate.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits confessions in police custody unless before magistrate; does not qualify s.25 ban.

concepts.unlisted_description: Ban on confessions in police custody except before magistrate.

The Indian Evidence Act does number define companyfession. For a long time, the Courts in India adopted the definition of companyfession given in Art. 22 of Stephens Digest of the Law of Evidence. According to that definition, a companyfession is an admission made at any time by a person charged with crime, stating or suggesting the inference that he companymitted that crime.

concepts.interpretation: A confession is an admission of the offence by a person charged with the offence. Must admit offence or substantially all facts constituting it. Self-exculpatory matter may negate if true. Whole statement including incriminating facts forms the confession.

anchor.surface_text: If the companyfession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is number permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a number- companyfessional statement.

concepts.interpretation: Entire confessional statement must be excluded if banned; cannot sever inculpatory from exculpatory or other incriminating parts. Applies to ss.24,25,26 Evidence Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Doctrine that taint affects whole confession; no partial admissibility except under s.27.

anchor.surface_text: Sections 17 to 31 of the Evidence Act are to he found under the heading Admissions. Confession is a species of admission, and is dealt with in ss. 24 to 30.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was charged under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code for murdering his aunt, Ratni, her daugh- ter. Chamin, her son-in-law, Somra and Dilu, son of somra.

issues.text: The principal question in the appeal is whether the statement or any portion of it is admissible in evidence

anchor.surface_text: The principal question in the appeal is whether the statement or any portion of it is admissible in evidence. The first information report reads as follows My name is Aghnu Nagesia.  1  My fathers name is Lodhi Nagesia. I am a resident of Lotwa, Tola Jamtoli, thana Palkot, district Ranchi.

issues.text: whether the entire statement is a confession made to a police officer and is not provable against the appellant, having regard to S. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, it is contended that the entire statement is a confession made to a police officer and is not provable against the appellant, having regard to S. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. On behalf of the respondent, it is contended that S. 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is not protected by s. 25.

issues.text: whether S. 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is not protected by s. 25

anchor.surface_text: S. 25 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. On behalf of the respondent, it is contended that S. 25 protects only those portions of the statement which disclose the killings by the appellant and the rest of the statement is not protected by s. 25. Section 25 of the Evidence Act is one of the provisions of law dealing with confessions made by an accused.

issues.text: the question whether apart from s. 27, a confessional first information report given by an accused is receivable in evidence against him

anchor.surface_text: Our attention is not drawn to any decision of this Court or of the Privy Council on the question whether apart from s. 27, a confessional first information report given by an accused is receivable in evidence against him. Decisions of the High Courts on this point are hopelessly conflicting.

issues.text: whether the appellant was in the custody of a police officer when he gave the report

anchor.surface_text: Broadly speaking, the High Court admitted in evidence parts 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 8, 10, 13, 15, 16, 17 and 18.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ing the accused as the maker of the report, numberpart of it companyld be tendered in evidence. We think, therefore, that save and except parts 1, 15

arguments.court_reasoning: Separability test misleading; entire confessional statement excluded except formal and s.27 parts

arguments.claim: Section 25 provides absolute ban: no confession made to a police officer shall be proved as against accused under any circumstances

anchor.surface_text: Section 25 provides No confession made to a police officer, shall be proved as against a person accused of an offence. The terms of s. 25 are imperative. A confession made to a police officer under any circumstances is not admissible

arguments.claim: Confession is an admission of the offence or substantially all facts constituting it; self-exculpatory matter may negate if true

anchor.surface_text: The Indian Evidence Act does not define confession... a confession is an admission made at any time by a person charged with crime, stating or suggesting the inference that he committed that crime. This definition was discarded... Pakala Narayanaswami

arguments.claim: Entire admission including exculpatory and inculpatory parts must be tendered; prosecution cannot use only inculpatory part

anchor.surface_text: If an admission of an accused is to be used against him, the whole of it should be tendered in evidence, and if part of the admission is exculpatory and part inculpatory, the prosecution is not at liberty to use in evidence the inculpatory part only.

arguments.claim: If confession tainted, taint attaches to each part; cannot separate and admit non-confessional parts

anchor.surface_text: If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is not permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a non-confessional statement.

arguments.claim: Every admission of incriminating fact in confessional statement partakes of character of confession

anchor.surface_text: Each part discloses some incriminating fact... though each part taken singly may not amount to a confession, each of them being part of a confessional statement partakes of the character of a confession.

arguments.claim: Hypothetical drunk driving statement under s.304A is whole confession even if no single sentence confesses

anchor.surface_text: Take a case of a person charged under s. 304-A... No single sentence in this statement amounts to a confession, but the statement read as a whole amounts to a confession

arguments.claim: Provisions ss.24-26 based on public policy distrusting police confessions; fullest effect to be given

anchor.surface_text: These provisions seem to proceed upon the view that confessions made by an accused to a police officer... are not to be trusted... They are based upon grounds of public policy, and the fullest effect should be given to them.

arguments.claim: Separability test of confessional FIR misleading; only formal parts and s.27 portions admissible

anchor.surface_text: We think that the separability test is misleading, and the entire confessional statement is hit by s. 25... save and except parts 1, 15 and 18... and save and except the portions coming within the purview of s. 27, the entire first information report must be excluded

arguments.claim: Appellant not in custody when giving FIR; s.27 inapplicable unless constructive custody
arguments.court_reasoning: Assume constructive custody for purposes of this case to admit discovery information

arguments.claim: Confessional FIR not substantive evidence but formal part admissible under s.8,21; non-confessional as admission

anchor.surface_text: If the first information is given by the accused himself, the fact of his giving the information is admissible... under s. 8... If the information is a non-confessional statement, it is admissible... under s. 21

holdings.text: The separability test is misleading, and the entire confessional statement is hit by s. 25 and save and except as provided by s. 27 and save and except the formal part identifying the accused as the maker of the report, no part of it could be tendered in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the separability test is misleading, and the entire confessional statement is hit by s. 25 and save and except as provided by s. 27 and save and except the formal part identifying the accused as the maker of the report, no part of it could be tendered in evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejected High Court separability approach; taint under s.25 affects whole statement including incriminating facts; distinguished conflicting High Court precedents; only formal parts and s.27 discovery portions admissible.

holdings.text: save and except parts 1, 15 and 18 identifying the appellant as the maker of the first information report and save and except the portions coming within the purview of s. 27, the entire first information report must be excluded from evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We think, therefore, that save and except parts 1, 15 and 18 identifying the appellant as the maker of the first information report and save and except the portions coming within the purview of s. 27, the entire first information report must be excluded from evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied inseparability doctrine to confessional FIR; formal introductory/concluding parts admissible to identify maker; rest excluded as part of tainted confession.

holdings.text: A confession made to a police officer under any circumstances is not admissible in evidence against the accused.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of s. 25 are imperative. A confession made to a police officer under any circumstances is not admissible in evidence against the accused. It covers a confession made when he was free and not in police custody, as also a confession made before any investigation has begun.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.25 imperative language; public policy distrust of police-obtained confessions; unqualified absolute ban.

holdings.text: If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is not permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a non-confessional statement.

anchor.surface_text: If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is not permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a non-confessional statement. Each part discloses some incriminating fact

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inculpatory/exculpatory parts inseparable; each incriminating admission partakes of confessional character; protects policy of ss.24-26.

holdings.text: For the purposes of the case, we shall assume that the appellant was constructively in police custody and therefore the information contained in the first information report leading to the discovery of the dead bodies and the tangi is admissible in evidence.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Prima facie not in custody but assumed constructive custody to apply s.27; discoveries follow from information given before formal arrest.

holdings.text: Section 26 does not qualify the absolute ban imposed by s. 25 on a confession made to a police officer.

anchor.surface_text: Section 26 does not qualify the absolute ban imposed by s. 25 on a confession made to a police officer. Section 27 is in the form of a proviso, and partially lifts the ban imposed by ss. 24, 25 and 26.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.26 partial ban for non-police only; s.25 absolute for police confessions; harmonious construction with s.27 proviso.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of s. 25 are imperative. A confession made to a police officer under any circumstances is not admissible in evidence against the accused. It covers a confession made when he was free and not in police custody, as also a confession made before any investigation has begun.

anchor.surface_text: If the confession is tainted, the taint attaches to each part of it. It is not permissible in law to separate one part and to admit it in evidence as a non-confessional statement. Each part discloses some incriminating fact
